{{Infobox person | name = Ruth Wilson | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1982|01|13}} | birth_place = [[Ashford, Surrey|Ashford]], [[Surrey]], England | occupation = [[Actress]] | years_active = 2005-present | height = | death_date = | death_place = | birth_name = Ruth Wilson | othername = | website = }} '''Ruth Wilson''' (born 13 January 1982) is an English actress, perhaps best known for her performance in the title role of ''[[Jane Eyre (2006 TV serial)|Jane Eyre]]''. ==Early life and education== Wilson was born in [[Ashford, Surrey|Ashford]], [[Surrey]] and raised with three older brothers in [[Shepperton]], [[Surrey]].Genower, Ellie [http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/film_and_tv/s/223/223611_ruth_is_following_footsteps_of_the_famous.html Ruth is following footsteps of the famous], ''Manchester Evening News'' (20 October 2006) She attended [[Notre Dame School (Surrey)|Notre Dame School]] and sixth form at [[Esher College]].Nichol, Patricia [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/theatre/article1830466.ece Something in the Eyre], ''[[Times Online]]'' (27 May 2007) As a teenager, Wilson worked as a model, and went on to study history at the [[University of Nottingham]], graduating in 2003. She graduated from the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]] in July 2005. Afterwards, she co-founded Hush Productions. While at Nottingham she was also involved in [[student drama]] at [[New Theatre (Nottingham)]] which later won an award for 'Outstanding Contribution to Student Theatre' at the [[National Student Drama Festival]] 2008. She currently lives in London.Hoggard, Liz [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20061007/ai_n17149948/pg_1 Ruth Wilson], ''[[The Independent]]'' (7 October 2006) She is a grand-daughter of the novelist and MI5 officer [[Alexander Wilson (writer and spy)|Alexander Wilson]].http://www.ma-radio.gold.ac.uk/cmle/timcrookbiog.htm ==Career== Prior to her role in ''[[Jane Eyre (2006 TV serial)|Jane Eyre]]'', Wilson had only one professional screen credit, in ''[[Suburban Shootout]]'', a [[situation comedy]]. Since then, Wilson has stated she is "going to better auditions. People are starting to see me, when they wouldn't have done, beforeâsuddenly you have done a big show, and have got a bit more standing."{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4780841.stm |title=Jane Eyre star's fast-rising fame |accessdate=2008-08-30 |work=[[BBC News]] |author=Stephen Robb | date=10 August 2006}} In 2006â7 she filmed the second series of ''Suburban Shootout'', a new ''[[Marple (TV series)|Marple]]'' mystery for [[ITV]], and [[Stephen Poliakoff]]'s [[BBC]] television drama ''[[Capturing Mary]]'' as the young Mary. In 2007 she appeared in Gorky's ''Philistines'', playing Tanya, at the [[Royal National Theatre|National]] from May until August 2007âand learned to play the piano for the role.Rock, Malcolm [http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821178631835 20 Questions Withâ¦ Ruth Wilson], ''What's on Stage'' (21 May 2007). She also narrated the audio book of Lauren St John's novel "The White Giraffe". In June 2007, Wilson presented the 2007 [[Lilian Baylis Awards]].Calvi, Nuala [http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/17158/jane-eyre-actress-wilson-presents-lilian Jane Eyre actress Wilson presents Lilian Baylis Awards], ''[[The Stage]]'' (12 June 2007). In November 2007, she gave a radio interview on BBC Radio 4 Woman's Hour{{citation | series = Woman's Hour Arts | title = Ruth Wilson | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/womanshour/02/2007_45_fri.shtml | publisher = BBC Radio 4}}. Other projects in 2007 included the narration of an audio book of the children's novel ''Dolphin Song'' by Lauren St John; a guest appearance in the [[sitcom]] ''[[Freezing (TV series)|Freezing]]'' as Alison Fennel (transmitted on BBC2, 21 February 2008); narration of the documentary ''The Polish Ambulance Murders'' (transmitted on BBC4, 5 February 2008); and the portrayal of a mentally ill doctor in the dramatised documentary ''The Doctor Who Hears Voices''[http://www.channel4.com/health/microsites/D/dr_hears_voices/programme.html ''The Doctor Who Hears Voices''], Channel 4 website (transmitted on UK Channel 4, 21 April 2008), a story which follows controversial psychologist Dr Rufus May as he treats a junior doctor diagnosed with bipolar disorder. During the winter of 2007 Wilson took six months off. She said: "I simply want to take a break and catch my breath. But I also think that, sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is to deliberately keep some time free and see what the world throws at you."Knight, Kathryn. "Bye Bye Bonnets", ''[[Daily Mail]]'' ''Weekend'', 2007-11-10. From 23 July to 3 October 2009 she appeared as Stella in the [[Donmar Warehouse|Donmar]] revival of ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]].''{{citation | url = http://www.donmarwarehouse.com/pl102info.html | publisher = Donmar Warehouse | title = Past Productions}}. On November 15, 2009 [[AMC (TV network)|AMC Television]] and [[ITV]] premiered the 2009 TV [[miniseries]] remake of ''[[The Prisoner (2009 miniseries)|The Prisoner]]'', in which Wilson played the Village doctor, "Number 313."{{citation | url = http://www.amctv.com/originals/the-prisoner/ | publisher = AMC TV | series = Originals | title = The Prisoner}}. Starting on BBC1 on 6 December 2009, she played "Queenie" in an adaptation of [[Andrea Levy|Andrea Levy's]] ''[[Small Island (television drama)|Small Island]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/tv/comingup/smallisland/|title=BBC - Small Island|work=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=15 August 2011}} which also aired in the United States on [[PBS]] in 2010. In 2010 she appeared in the UK psychological police drama ''[[Luther (TV series)|Luther]]'' as Alice Morgan, starring with [[Idris Elba]]. From 10 June to 31 July 2010 Wilson starred as Karin in the [[Almeida Theatre]] production of ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass Darkly]]'', an adaptation for the stage of [[Ingmar Bergman]]'s [[34th Academy Awards|Oscar-winning 1961]] film. From 4 August to 8 October 2011, alongside [[Jude Law]], Wilson is starring in the title role of [[Eugene O'Neill]]'s ''[[Anna Christie]]'' at the [[Donmar Warehouse]], a performance which prompted ''[[The Guardian]]'' to devote an [[editorial]] to Wilson's "courageous, edgy and compelling talent".{{cite news|title=In praise of â¦ Ruth Wilson|date=16 August 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|page=30|accessdate=16 August 2011|location=London}} ==Awards and nominations== Wilson's performance in ''[[Jane Eyre (2006 TV serial)|Jane Eyre]]'' earned her four nominations for Best Actress awards in 2007, from the [[Broadcasting Press Guild]], [[BAFTA]] television awards{{cite web |url=http://www.broadcastingpressguild.org/news/010307_bpg33noms.html |title=Nominations for Broadcasting Press Guild 33rd Annual Television and Radio Awards |accessdate=2007-07-26 |work=[[Broadcasting Press Guild]] }}{{cite web |url=http://www.bafta.org/site/page129.html |title=Latest Winners and Nominees |accessdate=2007-07-26 |work=[[BAFTA]] }} [[Satellite Awards]] and the [[65th Golden Globe Awards|2008 Golden Globes]]. She also came second in a BBC viewers' poll for Best Actress of 2006. She won the [[2010 Laurence Olivier Awards|2010 Olivier Award]] for Best Supporting Actress for her role as Stella in ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'' at the [[Donmar Warehouse]]. ==Selected credits== {| class="wikitable sortable" !
